questions.q: Where is the pain located in Appendicitis?
questions.rationale: The appendix is located in the Right Lower Quadrant (McBurney's Point).

questions.q: Why is the Pancreatitis patient kept NPO?
questions.rationale: Eating stimulates the pancreas to secrete enzymes, which digests the pancreas itself. NPO stops this process.

questions.q: What is the most dangerous electrolyte imbalance in renal failure?
questions.rationale: Hyperkalemia (High Potassium) can cause fatal cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.q: What drug is used to lower ammonia levels in cirrhosis?
questions.rationale: Lactulose traps ammonia in the gut and expels it via stool, treating hepatic encephalopathy.

questions.q: Which food group is lowest in fiber?
questions.rationale: Animal products (meat, milk, eggs) contain no dietary fiber.

questions.q: How many calories are in 1 gram of fat?
questions.rationale: Fats are the most calorie-dense nutrient at 9 kcal/gram.

questions.q: Which food produces Acid Ash?
questions.rationale: Acid ash diets acidify urine to prevent certain stones and infections.

questions.q: Which grain is allowed on a Gluten-Free diet?
questions.rationale: Rice and Corn are gluten-free. Remember 'BROW' to avoid: Barley, Rye, Oats, Wheat.

questions.q: What organism commonly causes Acute Glomerulonephritis?
questions.rationale: It is an immune complex reaction that occurs weeks after a Strep throat infection.

questions.q: Which colostomy can be irrigated?
questions.rationale: Only colostomies with formed stool (lower colon) can be trained via irrigation.

questions.q: How is Hepatitis A transmitted?
questions.rationale: Hep A is viral, transmitted via contaminated food/water (Fecal-Oral).

questions.q: What assessment finding is classic for Pyloric Stenosis?
questions.rationale: The thickened pyloric muscle feels like an olive in the epigastrum.

questions.q: What is the classic sign of intussusception?
questions.rationale: Stool mixed with blood and mucus looks like currant jelly.

questions.q: What type of stool is seen in Hirschsprung's Disease?
questions.rationale: Stool is forced through the narrowed segment, appearing ribbon-like.

questions.q: What is the best position for a client with Hiatal Hernia?
questions.rationale: Gravity helps keep the stomach contents down. Sit up after meals.

questions.q: What diet prevents Dumping Syndrome?
questions.rationale: Carbs and fluids speed up emptying. Protein and fat slow it down.

questions.q: What is the priority assessment for a client with ascites?
questions.rationale: Ascites puts pressure on the diaphragm, impairing breathing.

questions.q: What is a major complication of esophageal varices?
questions.rationale: These veins are fragile and can burst, causing life-threatening bleeding.

questions.q: Why must scissors be kept at the bedside with a Blakemore tube?
options: To cut the tube if airway is blocked
questions.rationale: If the balloon moves up and blocks the airway, you must cut the tube to deflate it instantly.

questions.q: What type of diet is recommended for Ulcerative Colitis?
questions.rationale: Low residue reduces bowel volume and irritation.

questions.q: Which disease is characterized by 'skip lesions'?
questions.rationale: Crohn's affects patchy areas of the GI tract, unlike UC which is continuous.

questions.q: What food should be avoided in Diverticulitis?
questions.rationale: Small seeds can get trapped in the diverticula and cause inflammation.

questions.q: Where does gallbladder pain typically radiate?
questions.rationale: Referred pain to the right shoulder is a classic sign of cholecystitis.

questions.q: What is a cardinal sign of Peritonitis?
questions.rationale: The abdomen becomes rigid due to muscle guarding against the severe inflammation.

questions.q: What EKG change is associated with Hypokalemia?
questions.rationale: U waves are a specific sign of low potassium.

questions.q: What is the first EKG sign of Hyperkalemia?
questions.rationale: Tall, peaked T waves indicate dangerous levels of potassium.

questions.q: What is a primary symptom of Hyponatremia?
questions.rationale: Sodium regulates fluid balance; low sodium causes brain swelling (cerebral edema).

questions.q: What is a common sign of Hypernatremia?
questions.rationale: High sodium draws water out of cells, causing dehydration signs.

questions.q: What signs indicate Hypocalcemia?
questions.rationale: Low calcium causes neuromuscular irritability and spasms.

questions.q: What is a symptom of Hypercalcemia?
questions.rationale: High calcium acts as a sedative on the muscles and nerves.

questions.q: What is the difference between a Duodenal Ulcer and a Gastric Ulcer in relation to food?
options: Duodenal pain is relieved by food; Gastric pain is worsened by food
questions.rationale: Feed a Duodenal Ulcer (food buffers acid), Starve a Gastric Ulcer (food stimulates acid secretion and worsens pain).

questions.q: What position should a client with Acute Pancreatitis assume for pain relief?
options: Fetal position (side-lying with knees drawn up)
questions.rationale: The fetal position reduces tension on the abdomen and decreases the pain of pancreatitis.

questions.q: What is Turner's Sign and what does it indicate?
options: Bluish discoloration of the flanks; acute pancreatitis
Yellowing of the skin; liver failure
Red streaking on the skin; cellulitis
questions.rationale: Turner's Sign (bluish discoloration of the flanks) indicates retroperitoneal hemorrhage, commonly seen in acute pancreatitis.

questions.q: What is Cullen's Sign and what does it indicate?
options: Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus; acute pancreatitis
questions.rationale: Cullen's Sign (bluish/purplish discoloration around the periumbilical region) indicates intra-abdominal hemorrhage, commonly seen with acute pancreatitis.

questions.q: What enzyme causes the pancreas to digest itself in pancreatitis?
questions.rationale: Trypsin is the proteolytic enzyme responsible for autodigestion (self-digestion) of the pancreas in acute pancreatitis.

questions.q: What is Murphy's Sign?
options: Pain when palpating the right costal margin during inspiration; gallbladder or liver disease
Rebound tenderness in the RLQ; appendicitis
questions.rationale: Murphy's Sign is pain on palpation of the right costal margin during deep inspiration. It is positive in cholecystitis (gallbladder inflammation) or liver disease.

questions.q: What is the hallmark stool finding in Ulcerative Colitis?
questions.rationale: Ulcerative Colitis causes bloody diarrhea (blood and mucus) due to continuous inflammation of the colonic mucosa.

questions.q: What additional finding is seen with Pyloric Stenosis besides an olive-shaped mass?
questions.rationale: Pyloric Stenosis presents with an olive-shaped epigastric mass AND projectile vomiting in infants, typically at 2-4 weeks of age.

questions.q: What additional finding is seen with Intussusception besides currant jelly stool?
questions.rationale: Intussusception presents with currant jelly stool (blood and mucus) AND a sausage-shaped mass in the right upper quadrant, along with episodic severe abdominal pain.

questions.q: What is Hirschsprung's Disease?
options: Absence of ganglionic cells in the colon causing lack of peristalsis
questions.rationale: Hirschsprung's Disease (congenital megacolon) is caused by the absence of ganglionic (nerve) cells in a segment of the colon, resulting in no peristalsis. Suspect if no meconium within 24 hours or ribbon-like foul-smelling stool.

questions.q: When should the nurse hold a tube feeding?
options: If residual volume is greater than 100 mL
questions.rationale: A residual greater than 100 mL indicates the stomach has not emptied properly, increasing aspiration risk. Hold the feeding, return the aspirate, and notify the provider.

questions.q: What should the nurse do during NG tube insertion if the patient coughs and gags?
options: Back off a little, let the patient calm, have them sip water, and advance again
questions.rationale: Coughing and gagging during insertion may mean the tube is entering the trachea. Stop, pull back slightly, allow the patient to calm down, offer sips of water through a straw, and advance again.

questions.q: How is the length of an NG tube measured before insertion?
options: From the mouth to the stomach
From the end of the nose, to the ear lobe, to the xyphoid process
From the chin to the umbilicus
questions.rationale: The NEX measurement (Nose to Ear to Xyphoid) estimates the distance to the stomach, approximately 22-26 inches in adults.

questions.q: How do you confirm NG tube placement?
options: Listen for air bubbles over the stomach only
Aspirate stomach contents and test pH (should be less than 4)
Ask the patient if they feel it in their stomach
questions.rationale: Aspirating gastric contents and testing pH (should be <4, acidic) is the best bedside confirmation of gastric placement. X-ray is the gold standard.

questions.q: What should the nurse do when removing an NG tube?
options: Have the patient take a deep breath and hold it, then remove quickly
Remove slowly while the patient exhales
questions.rationale: Having the patient take a deep breath and hold it closes the epiglottis, preventing aspiration of any residual contents as the tube is withdrawn in one smooth motion.

questions.q: What should the nurse do after administering medications through an NG tube?
options: Turn off NG suction for 30 minutes
questions.rationale: Turn off NG suction for at least 30 minutes after giving PO medications through the tube to allow adequate absorption before suctioning resumes.

questions.q: What is the purpose of a Miller Abbott tube?
options: Advancement into the small intestine for decompression
questions.rationale: The Miller Abbott tube is a long intestinal tube advanced (via the right side) into the small intestine for decompression of intestinal obstruction.

questions.q: In which position should the patient be placed for an enema?
questions.rationale: Left Sims position allows the solution to flow by gravity into the sigmoid colon, following the natural anatomy of the descending colon.

questions.q: What IV fluid should ALWAYS be used with blood products?
questions.rationale: Normal Saline is the ONLY solution compatible with blood products. Dextrose solutions cause hemolysis, and Lactated Ringer's contains calcium which causes clotting.

questions.q: What gauge needle is used for blood transfusion?
questions.rationale: An 18-19 gauge needle is used for blood transfusions. The tubing must have a filter, and blood must be administered within 30 minutes of hanging.

questions.q: What is the first action if a transfusion reaction is suspected?
options: Stop the transfusion and keep the vein open with NS
questions.rationale: Stop the blood immediately to prevent further reaction. Keep the IV patent with Normal Saline, then notify the provider, save the blood bag, and send labs.

questions.q: How many RNs must check blood products before administration?
questions.rationale: Two RNs must independently verify the blood product against the patient's ID, including blood type, Rh factor, expiration date, and unit number to prevent transfusion errors.

questions.q: What is the monitoring schedule during a blood transfusion?
options: Vitals before, 15 min after start, then 30 min, then hourly up to 1 hour after
questions.rationale: Monitor vitals: before, during (15 min after start, then every 30 min), and after infusion (up to 1 hour). Stay with the patient for the first 15 minutes when reactions are most likely.

questions.q: What should be checked on a blood product before administration?
options: Expiration date, clots, color, air bubbles, leaks
Name and date of birth only
questions.rationale: Inspect the blood product for expiration date, clots, abnormal color, air bubbles, and leaks. Do not use if any abnormalities are found.

questions.q: Which solutions are considered isotonic?
options: D5W, Normal Saline (0.9% NaCl), Lactated Ringer's
questions.rationale: Isotonic solutions (D5W, NS, LR) have the same osmolality as blood and do not cause fluid shifts. NS is the only solution used with blood products and Dilantin.

questions.q: What foods are high in Potassium (K+)?
options: Bananas, dried fruits, citrus, potatoes, legumes, tea, peanut butter
questions.rationale: Potassium-rich foods include bananas, oranges, potatoes, dried fruits, legumes, tomatoes, avocados, and peanut butter.

questions.q: What foods are high in Calcium (Ca++)?
options: Milk, cheese, green leafy vegetables, legumes
questions.rationale: Calcium-rich foods include dairy products (milk, cheese, yogurt), green leafy vegetables, legumes, and fortified foods.

questions.q: What foods are high in Iron (Fe++)?
options: Green leafy vegetables, red meat, organ meat, eggs, whole wheat, carrots
questions.rationale: Iron-rich foods include red meat, organ meats, green leafy vegetables, eggs, whole wheat, and carrots. Use Z-track for iron injections to avoid skin staining.

questions.q: What technique should be used for Iron injections to prevent skin staining?
questions.rationale: Z-track injection displaces the skin before injecting to seal the medication in the muscle and prevent iron from leaking back through the tissue, which causes permanent brown staining.

questions.q: What is Chvostek's Sign?
options: Carpal spasm with BP cuff inflation; hypocalcemia
Facial spasm after tapping the facial nerve; hypocalcemia
Fanning of toes; upper motor neuron lesion
questions.rationale: Chvostek's Sign is facial muscle twitching/spasm when the facial nerve (in front of the ear) is tapped. It indicates hypocalcemia (hypoparathyroidism).

questions.q: What is Trousseau's Sign?
options: Facial spasm after facial nerve tap
Carpal spasm induced by BP cuff inflation; hypocalcemia
questions.rationale: Trousseau's Sign is carpal spasm (hand/wrist contraction) when a BP cuff is inflated on the arm for 3 minutes. It indicates hypocalcemia (hypoparathyroidism).

questions.q: What EKG changes are seen with Hypokalemia?
options: Peaked T waves, prolonged PR, wide QRS
Prominent U waves, depressed ST segment, flat T waves
questions.rationale: Hypokalemia causes prominent U waves, depressed ST segment, and flat T waves on EKG. It can lead to dangerous arrhythmias.

questions.q: What EKG changes are seen with Hyperkalemia?
options: U waves and flat T waves
Tall peaked T waves, prolonged PR interval, wide QRS
questions.rationale: Hyperkalemia causes tall peaked T waves, prolonged PR interval, and widened QRS complex. Severe hyperkalemia can progress to ventricular fibrillation and cardiac arrest.

questions.q: What is the normal range for serum Potassium (K+)?
questions.rationale: Normal K+ is 3.5-5.0 mEq/L. Below 3.5 is hypokalemia; above 5.0 is hyperkalemia. Both extremes are dangerous for the heart.

questions.q: What is the normal range for serum Sodium (Na+)?
questions.rationale: Normal Na+ is 136-145 mEq/L. Sodium is the major extracellular cation and regulates fluid balance.

questions.q: What is the normal range for serum Calcium (Ca++)?
questions.rationale: Normal Ca++ is 9-10.5 mg/dL. Hypocalcemia causes tetany and spasms; hypercalcemia causes sedation and kidney stones.

questions.q: What is the normal range for serum Magnesium (Mg+)?
questions.rationale: Normal Mg+ is 1.5-2.5 mEq/L. Magnesium is important for neuromuscular function. Low Mg causes symptoms similar to hypocalcemia.

questions.q: What is the normal BUN range?
questions.rationale: Normal BUN is 10-20 mg/dL. Elevated BUN indicates impaired renal function, dehydration, or high protein intake.

questions.q: What is the normal Creatinine range?
questions.rationale: Normal Creatinine is 0.5-1.2 mg/dL. It is the most reliable indicator of renal function because it is not affected by diet or hydration.

questions.q: What dietary restriction is important for a client with renal failure?
questions.rationale: Protein restriction reduces the workload on the kidneys by decreasing nitrogenous waste (BUN) production. Also restrict potassium, sodium, and phosphorus.

questions.q: What are the three phases of acute renal failure?
questions.rationale: The three phases are: Oliguric (decreased urine output, fluid overload), Diuretic (massive urine output, risk of dehydration), and Recovery (gradual return of renal function).

questions.q: What is the difference between pre-renal, intra-renal, and post-renal failure?
options: Pre-renal = perfusion problem; Intra-renal = kidney damage; Post-renal = obstruction
Pre-renal = infection; Intra-renal = toxins; Post-renal = dehydration
questions.rationale: Pre-renal: interference with renal perfusion (shock, dehydration). Intra-renal: damage to renal parenchyma (nephrotoxic drugs, glomerulonephritis). Post-renal: obstruction from tubules to urethral meatus (stones, tumors, BPH).

questions.q: What is the minimum urine output that indicates adequate kidney function?
questions.rationale: A urine output of 30 mL/hr indicates minimal competency of heart and kidney function. Below this level, notify the provider.

questions.q: Where is flank pain located and what does it indicate?
options: Side/back between ribs and hip; kidney stone in upper ureter
questions.rationale: Flank pain indicates a stone in the kidney or upper ureter. Abdominal/scrotal pain suggests a stone in the mid/lower ureter or bladder.

questions.q: What type of solution is used for bladder irrigation?
questions.rationale: Only isotonic sterile saline is used for bladder irrigation to prevent fluid and electrolyte imbalances.

questions.q: How is Hepatitis B primarily transmitted?
questions.rationale: Hepatitis B is transmitted through blood, sexual contact, and perinatal exposure. It is more infectious than HIV. Healthcare workers should be vaccinated.

questions.q: What is the most common cause of cirrhosis in the US?
options: Hepatitis C and chronic alcohol use
questions.rationale: Chronic alcohol abuse and Hepatitis C are the leading causes of cirrhosis, which causes irreversible scarring and impaired liver function.

questions.q: What is hepatic encephalopathy?
options: Brain dysfunction caused by elevated ammonia from liver failure
questions.rationale: When the liver cannot convert ammonia to urea, ammonia accumulates in the blood and crosses the blood-brain barrier, causing confusion, asterixis (liver flap), and eventual coma.

questions.q: What diet modification is essential in hepatic encephalopathy?
questions.rationale: Protein restriction reduces ammonia production from protein metabolism. Lactulose and Neomycin are used to reduce ammonia levels.

questions.q: What is asterixis and what does it indicate?
options: Flapping hand tremor; hepatic encephalopathy (liver failure)
questions.rationale: Asterixis (liver flap) is an involuntary flapping tremor of the hands when wrists are dorsiflexed. It is a classic sign of hepatic encephalopathy from elevated ammonia.

questions.q: What lab value is most specific to liver damage?
questions.rationale: ALT is the most liver-specific enzyme. Elevated ALT and AST indicate hepatocellular damage. Also monitor bilirubin, albumin, PT/INR, and ammonia.

questions.q: What causes clay-colored (acholic) stools?
options: Absence of bile in the stool (biliary obstruction)
questions.rationale: Bile gives stool its normal brown color. When bile flow is obstructed (gallstones, pancreatic head tumor), stool becomes pale/clay-colored and urine becomes dark (tea-colored).

questions.q: What is the difference between Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis?
options: Crohn's = skip lesions, full wall thickness, any part of GI; UC = continuous, mucosal only, colon only
Crohn's is limited to the colon; UC affects the whole GI tract
Crohn's causes bloody diarrhea; UC does not
questions.rationale: Crohn's: skip lesions, transmural (full wall thickness), can affect mouth to anus, cobblestone appearance, fistulas. UC: continuous inflammation, mucosal layer only, limited to colon/rectum, bloody diarrhea.

questions.q: What are the complications of Crohn's Disease?
options: Fistulas, abscesses, strictures, malabsorption, bowel obstruction
questions.rationale: Crohn's causes transmural inflammation leading to fistulas (abnormal connections between organs), abscesses, strictures, malabsorption (especially B12 and fat-soluble vitamins), and bowel obstruction.

questions.q: What complication of Ulcerative Colitis is a medical emergency?
questions.rationale: Toxic megacolon is a life-threatening dilation of the colon that can lead to perforation, sepsis, and death. Signs: fever, tachycardia, abdominal distension, absent bowel sounds.

questions.q: What is the nurse's priority when a client has a new colostomy?
options: Assessing stoma color (should be beefy red and moist)
questions.rationale: The stoma should be beefy red, moist, and slightly edematous initially. A pale, dusky, or black stoma indicates ischemia and must be reported immediately.

questions.q: What is the consistency of output from an ileostomy vs. a sigmoid colostomy?
questions.rationale: The higher in the GI tract the ostomy, the more liquid the output. Ileostomy output is liquid to loose (risk of dehydration/electrolyte loss). Sigmoid colostomy output is formed.

questions.q: What position should the client be in for a liver biopsy?
options: Left lateral with right arm above head
Right side-lying with pillow/towel against puncture site
questions.rationale: After a liver biopsy, position on the RIGHT side with a pillow/towel against the puncture site. This applies pressure to prevent hemorrhage from the highly vascular liver.

questions.q: What electrolyte imbalances should the nurse monitor for in a patient on diuretics?
questions.rationale: Loop diuretics (Lasix) waste potassium, sodium, and magnesium. Monitor labs and replace as needed. Potassium-sparing diuretics (Aldactone/Spironolactone) can cause hyperkalemia.

questions.q: What is the potassium-sparing diuretic and what must you watch for?
questions.rationale: Spironolactone (Aldactone) is a potassium-sparing diuretic. Watch for hyperkalemia. Also used with ACE inhibitors, which also retain potassiumâ€”double risk.

questions.q: What are the signs and symptoms of a bowel obstruction?
options: Abdominal distension, vomiting, absent bowel sounds, cramping pain
questions.rationale: Bowel obstruction causes: vomiting (may be fecal), abdominal distension, high-pitched bowel sounds initially progressing to absent bowel sounds, cramping pain, and inability to pass stool or gas.

questions.q: What is the difference between a small bowel and large bowel obstruction?
options: Small bowel = early vomiting, rapid dehydration; Large bowel = gradual distension, constipation
Large bowel = early vomiting; Small bowel = constipation
questions.rationale: Small bowel obstructions cause early, frequent vomiting and rapid dehydration. Large bowel obstructions cause gradual abdominal distension and constipation with later vomiting.

questions.q: What nursing action is priority for suspected appendicitis?
options: Apply a heating pad to the abdomen
Keep NPO, do NOT apply heat, do NOT give enemas or laxatives
questions.rationale: With suspected appendicitis: keep NPO (prep for surgery), NO heat (increases risk of rupture), NO enemas/laxatives (increase peristalsis and risk of perforation). Monitor for peritonitis signs.

questions.q: What is GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease)?
options: Backward flow of stomach acid into the esophagus
questions.rationale: GERD occurs when the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) is weakened, allowing gastric acid to reflux into the esophagus causing heartburn, regurgitation, and esophageal damage.

questions.q: What lifestyle modifications should be taught for GERD?
options: Eat large meals and lie down after eating
Elevate HOB 30 degrees, small frequent meals, avoid eating 2-3 hours before bed
questions.rationale: GERD management: elevate HOB, small frequent meals, avoid trigger foods (caffeine, chocolate, spicy, fatty), no eating before bed, maintain healthy weight, avoid tight clothing.

questions.q: What does a positive Guaiac (occult blood) test indicate?
questions.rationale: A positive guaiac test indicates occult (hidden) blood in the stool, which may indicate GI bleeding from ulcers, polyps, or colorectal cancer. Further evaluation (colonoscopy) is needed.

questions.q: What is the Albumin level used to assess?
questions.rationale: Albumin (normal 3.5-5 g/dL) is produced by the liver and reflects both liver function and nutritional status. Low albumin indicates malnutrition or liver disease and causes edema (decreased oncotic pressure).

questions.q: How many calories are in 1 gram of protein and 1 gram of carbohydrate?
questions.rationale: Both protein and carbohydrates provide 4 kcal/gram. Fat provides 9 kcal/gram. Alcohol provides 7 kcal/gram.

questions.q: A client with cirrhosis develops esophageal varices. Which intervention is the HIGHEST priority?
options: Prepare for balloon tamponade or banding
questions.rationale: Bleeding esophageal varices are a life-threatening emergency. Balloon tamponade (Sengstaken-Blakemore tube) or endoscopic banding/sclerotherapy is the priority to control hemorrhage. Lactulose is for hepatic encephalopathy, not acute variceal bleeding.

questions.q: Which assessment finding is MOST concerning after a client undergoes a paracentesis?
questions.rationale: Paracentesis removes large volumes of ascitic fluid. Rapid fluid shifts can cause hypovolemia leading to shock (tachycardia, hypotension, dizziness). Monitor VS closely and administer IV albumin as ordered to maintain intravascular volume.
